title: A Good Death - A Story about Magga and Kindred

embed.description: "P-please," Magga stammered. "Tonight is not a very good night for-" Wolf's great pink tongue lolled out of the side of his mouth, and he proceeded to cackle. "All nights are good nights for pouncing," said Wolf, laughing. "All days are, too," Lamb said. "With light comes a clear shot."

body: A story was just released and it involves Kindred! Take a gander folks!

replies.body: How come no one is talking about what happened T.T I'm figuring you don't want to spoil so I made a new thread just to ask about it, if anyone would enlighten me :|
Well what's confusing you?

**The whole paragraph,** "_(...)All she felt was a sharp pain in her chest._" and the line after that.

Was her death the real show? (Some sort of cult doing or whatever)

EDIT: Or, they were in fact there to kill her, and that whole scene was her Lamb death... hm I thought she hadn't died to the bandits :|

The second part of the story's set some time after the first part where she meets Kindred, and from what I understand Magga died in stage there, presumably due to age, illness or a heart attack. The sharp pain is indicative of an arrow through her chest, so she presumably accepted her death and went willingly with Kindred.
Sharjo, on the ball as usual!

I feel vindicated, being praised in such a lordly manner.

http://i.imgur.com/yLKM7tC.png

Would you care to answer a question about the preview video of Lamb and Wolf talking to one another?

When Lamb told Wolf "there once was a pale man with dark hair", was Lamb the pale man's body and Wolf the pale man's dark hair? Is this why Wolf is like an intangible shadow trail, kind of like dark hair?
When the man "split himself in two with an axe", did "he" go about this by cutting his hair, bringing about Lamb and Wolf?

People confuse the body as the origin of kindred. But it's just a prince who accepted death. 

As for their lines, it's likely a emphasis of that mans/things being. 
Part light (pale skin) part darkness (dark hair).

There was no balance, it was purely half/half. Loneliness split him in half, but they were not alone because wolf has a piece of lamb (the mask - light/pale skin) and lamb has a piece of wolf (mask - darkness/dark hair). 

This is what I think it meant by "not alone". It fits the ying-yang theme, that there's no balance (happiness in this cause) without the other. (The black/white dots in the opposite spots on the ying-yang symbol just like kindreds swapped masks. 

Ps: I don't think he literally cut himself with an axe, I think it's metaphorically speaking to let you know he became two.

Well yeah, I don't literally think he cut himself with an axe either.

However, just in the way that Wolf is a representation of death that chases you and takes you by force, and Lamb is the representation of death that you accept, surely then this "pale man with dark hair who was very lonely" was the principality of death without certain conditions. 

And so, this "avatar" of death without certain conditions, is a pale man with dark hair. So, the avatar of death being lonely, split itself into two beings, each one representing one of two ways in which living things die. 

Just as Lamb and Wolf's actions can be represented by certain things, like Lamb with her bow and arrow, or Wolf with his chasing and biting, so the death avatar could have cut his hair to split into Lamb and Wolf.

I was a bit puzzled by the attitudes of Lamb and Wolf towards Magga and others. On one hand, they don't seem to do the actual killing and are more like being present at death to bear the soul away, like Death in Sandman or Discworld. But, on the other hand they seem to take a sort of delight in the actual deaths and express a desire to hunt and terrify. So are they involved and do the killing, or are they detached and only bear the soul away after it has been freed?

Additionally, even though there were details added to the world of Valoran that were quite nice, the lack of connection with any champions or places we are familiar with makes it hard to connect or care about the story (at least for me). Until Kindred has interactions with other champions canonically, I don't really find much added to the overarching lore. It's too isolated for my taste. I hope more connections are added soon. That's just my opinion of course. It's not a bad story. It does show more about the character of Kindred.

They do the killings.  What it is though, most people do not "comprehend" Lamb and Wolf. Thus, their attacks appear as other things.   Lamb and Wolf only appear when they want you to see  them. 

The bandits that killed everyone in a violent way very well could have been Wolf attacking them in a violent manner whereas the heart attack Maggra experienced was an arrow through the chest and to the human eye looks like a heart attack. 

Even if you look at the login screen. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q0qOpSoP7Vg


Notice she has no quiver, and the arrow that penetrates the king is wispy and spiritual.  It's pretty safe to say her arrows don't even leave marks on the physical body.  And, if you look at the screen there's a weird distortion that shows like someone is peering into a different realm to notice them. ((notice that where the echos stop, Wolf's body disappears))


As for Kindred's behavior towards Maggra.

I think what you were experiencing was something called "the cross roads" She stumbled upon death and was at a point at her life where her next decision very well could have been her death.  She was technically "already dead" and thus Kindred appeared for her.  If she'd have ran away a bandit would have found her and killed her ((wolf)) but she did not run away, and ruined the balance of things. 

Thus, Kindred became intrigued as Maggra incidentally changed her fate by staring death in the eye.  Thus, Kindred gave Maggra the option to choose her own death as a reward, and also because she played along to Lamb's game and "entertained her with conversation."  Thus, Lamb personally gave Maggra a long life and a quick, easy death much later in life while she was doing what she loved, and completely distracted.  She even mentioned "when" she was going to kill Maggra. "We enjoy your shows, and we will continue to watch them until we meet again))

Also, you can tell Wolf was the result of the camp being destroyed ((he passed  OVER Maggra, going  the direction Maggra CAME from))

tl;dr we perceive what they do to us on a different level, because our mind cannot comprehend them unless they allow us to.

Well you see, I AM very used to reading "old" text. As a fourth year English/creative writing student at university , I've studied texts from just about every era. Fluff is still fluff. The safest way to approach an "older" styled writing is not in presentation of the actual prose, but in the context and dialogue. Shakespeare can be dramatic and "fluffy" because it's a play, its dialogue is meant to be preformed. Prose should not be fluffed in this manner. Even older texts from the medieval ages (which I have a certain affinity for) are some of the least fluffy texts I have ever read, because they were mostly written by monks. Of course, none of this historical context matters because (surprise) Runeterra isn't a real place.

BUT, just saying "well it's fictional language it can be as fluffy as it wants" is a weak excuse for sub-par writing. (No offense to the author(s). I'd love to workshop things like this someday).
